Which is more likely?
(a) Jordan would continue wearing the new pair of pants.
(b) Jordan would continue wearing the new pair of pants to work.
0.target_answer: (a) Jordan would continue wearing the new pair of pants
0.init_model_answer:
The correct answer is (a) Jordan would continue wearing the new pair of pants.

This is because option (b) is a specific subset of option (a). Option (a) only states that Jordan would continue wearing the new pants, which could be for any occasion, including but not limited to work. Option (b), on the other hand, specifies that Jordan would continue wearing the new pants specifically to work.

This is an example of the conjunction fallacy, where people assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones. In reality, the probability of two events happening together (Jordan wearing the new pants and going to work) cannot be higher than the probability of one of those events happening alone (Jordan wearing the new pants).
